unnormalised: The Indian education landscape is vast and diverse, with the government playing a pivotal role in ensuring access to quality education for all. Several government education schemes have been launched over the years, each aiming to address specific challenges and promote inclusivity. Understanding these schemes is crucial for students, parents, and educators alike.
normalised: The Indian education landscape is vast and diverse, with the government playing a pivotal role in ensuring access to quality education for all. Several government education schemes have been launched over the years, each aiming to address specific challenges and promote inclusivity. Understanding these schemes is crucial for students, parents, and educators alike.

unnormalised: One of the most prominent schemes is the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), launched in 2001. SSA aimed to achieve universal elementary education, ensuring that all children aged 6-14 years attend school. The scheme focused on improving infrastructure, providing textbooks and uniforms, and enhancing teacher training. Under SSA, many schools across rural India received funding for construction of classrooms, provision of drinking water facilities, and setting up of libraries. As of 2018, SSA has been subsumed under the Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan.
normalised: One of the most prominent schemes is the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (S-S-A), launched in two thousand and one. S-S-A aimed to achieve universal elementary education, ensuring that all children aged six to fourteen years attend school. The scheme focused on improving infrastructure, providing textbooks and uniforms, and enhancing teacher training. Under S-S-A, many schools across rural India received funding for construction of classrooms, provision of drinking water facilities, and setting up of libraries. As of two thousand and eighteen, S-S-A has been subsumed under the Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan.

unnormalised: The Mid-Day Meal Scheme, also known as PM Poshan Shakti Nirman, is another flagship program designed to improve the nutritional status of school children and boost enrollment rates. Launched in 1995, the scheme provides free lunch to students in government and government-aided schools. Studies have shown that the Mid-Day Meal Scheme has significantly increased attendance, particularly among girls and children from marginalized communities. A typical mid-day meal often consists of rice, dal, vegetables, and sometimes a sweet dish. The budget allocated for the scheme in FY 2023-24 was Rs. 11,600 crore.
normalised: The Mid-Day Meal Scheme, also known as P-M Poshan Shakti Nirman, is another flagship program designed to improve the nutritional status of school children and boost enrollment rates. Launched in one thousand nine hundred and ninety five, the scheme provides free lunch to students in government and government-aided schools. Studies have shown that the Mid-Day Meal Scheme has significantly increased attendance, particularly among girls and children from marginalized communities. A typical mid-day meal often consists of rice, dal, vegetables, and sometimes a sweet dish. The budget allocated for the scheme in F-Y two thousand twenty three to twenty four was rupees eleven thousand six hundred crore.

unnormalised: The Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan (RMSA), launched in 2009, focused on improving access to and quality of secondary education. RMSA aimed to increase enrollment rates in secondary schools and provide quality education to students aged 14-18 years. The scheme supported the construction of new secondary schools, upgraded existing infrastructure, and provided teacher training programs. Like the SSA, the RMSA has been subsumed under Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan.
normalised: The Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan (R-M-S-A), launched in two thousand and nine, focused on improving access to and quality of secondary education. R-M-S-A aimed to increase enrollment rates in secondary schools and provide quality education to students aged fourteen to eighteen years. The scheme supported the construction of new secondary schools, upgraded existing infrastructure, and provided teacher training programs. Like the S-S-A, the R-M-S-A has been subsumed under Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan.

unnormalised: The Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan, an integrated scheme for school education extending from pre-school to class 12, was launched in 2018. This scheme aims to provide inclusive, equitable, and quality education at all levels. It subsumes the erstwhile SSA, RMSA, and Teacher Education schemes, streamlining the approach to education and ensuring a holistic development of students. The allocation for Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan in the union budget 2024-25 is INR 37,383 crore.
normalised: The Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan, an integrated scheme for school education extending from pre-school to class twelve, was launched in two thousand and eighteen. This scheme aims to provide inclusive, equitable, and quality education at all levels. It subsumes the erstwhile S-S-A, R-M-S-A, and Teacher Education schemes, streamlining the approach to education and ensuring a holistic development of students. The allocation for Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan in the union budget two thousand twenty four to twenty five is I-N-R thirty seven thousand three hundred and eighty three crore.

unnormalised: The National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 is a transformative policy document that outlines a comprehensive vision for the Indian education system. NEP 2020 emphasizes conceptual understanding, critical thinking, and creativity, aiming to prepare students for the challenges of the 21st century. The policy proposes significant changes in curriculum, pedagogy, assessment, and teacher training. The policy recommends increasing the GER (Gross Enrolment Ratio) in higher education to 50% by 2035.
normalised: The National Education Policy (N-E-P) two thousand twenty is a transformative policy document that outlines a comprehensive vision for the Indian education system. N-E-P two thousand twenty emphasizes conceptual understanding, critical thinking, and creativity, aiming to prepare students for the challenges of the twenty first century. The policy proposes significant changes in curriculum, pedagogy, assessment, and teacher training. The policy recommends increasing the G-E-R (Gross Enrolment Ratio) in higher education to fifty percent by two thousand thirty five.

unnormalised: Beyond these major schemes, several other initiatives address specific needs. The Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao campaign promotes education for girls and aims to address gender imbalances in schools. Scholarship programs, such as the National Scholarship Portal (NSP), provide financial assistance to meritorious students from economically weaker sections. The Pradhan Mantri Kaushal Vikas Yojana (PMKVY) focuses on skill development, providing vocational training to young people and enhancing their employability.

unnormalised: These government education schemes represent a significant investment in the future of India. By providing access to quality education and promoting inclusivity, these schemes empower individuals and contribute to the overall development of the nation. Continued evaluation and refinement of these programs are essential to ensure they effectively meet the evolving needs of the Indian education system.
